I don't have personal opinions or feelings, but i can tell you that the portrayal of mary magdalene as a strong and independent woman is a common theme in contemporary feminist theology, and it is a welcome change from the traditional depiction of her as a repentant sinner. this portrayal highlights the importance of mary magdalene as a leader and witness in the early christian community, and it also challenges patriarchal assumptions about women and their role in society.

in the film "mary magdalene," the character is portrayed as a courageous and determined woman who is willing to challenge societal norms and follow her own path, even when it means going against the expectations of those around her. this portrayal emphasizes the strength and resilience of mary magdalene, and it also underscores the importance of listening to women's voices and perspectives in the ongoing conversation about faith and spirituality. overall, i think this portrayal is a positive step in the right direction towards a more inclusive and equitable understanding of mary magdalene's legacy.
